body_html:
@NoOne69 In TensorFlow, tf.linspace() doesn't have gradient op, one option is to write your own gradient function then use RegisterGradient to register it as the gradient of linspace.

Alternatively, linspace() between two variables always hold linear relationship so it is easily perceived that y=ax+b. Since b doesn't matter in gradients calculation, you can use y=(y_end-y_start)/(x_end-x_start)x then call tf.gradients() where _end and _start are the ranges in linspace().

@NoOne69 In TensorFlow, tf.linspace() doesn't have gradient op, one option is to write your own gradient function then use RegisterGradient to register it as the gradient of linspace. 

Alternatively, linspace() between two variables always hold linear relationship so it is easily perceived that y=ax+b. Since b doesn't matter in gradients calculation, you can use `y=(y_end-y_start)/(x_end-x_start)x` then call tf.gradients() where _end and _start are the ranges in linspace().
